qụi subdit pòpulum meum sub me. ^ My mercy
column8: and I have hoped in him
column9: who subdueth my people under me.

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: qụia innotuìsti ei~? Aŭt fílius hòminis
that thou art made known to him~? or the son of man
column6: that thou makest account of him~?

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 4 ^ Hòmo vanitáti sìmilis factus est~; dies ejus sicut ùmbra praĕtèreunt. ^ Man is like to vanity~; his days pass away like a shadow.

who teacheth my hands to fight: bow down thy heavens and descend~; touch the mountains

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: et dissipábis eos~; emìtte saģìttas tuas
et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: et conturbábis eos. ^ Send forth lightning
who teacheth my hands to fight: and thou shalt scatter them~; shoot out thy arrows

et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: et líbera me de aqụîs mùltîs
^ Put forth thy hand from on high
column7: and deliver me from many waters
column8: from the hand of strange children

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: et dèxtera eórum dèxtera iniqụitátis. ^ whose mouth hath spoken vanity
et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity.

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: cánticum novum cantábo tìbi~; in psaltério
I will sing a new canticle~; on the psaltery and an instrument of ten strings I will sing praises to thee

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: qụi redemìsti Davídem servum tuum de gládio malìgno. ^ who givest salvation to kings~; who hast redeemed thy servant David from the malicious sword.
et érue me de manu filiórum alienórum
column6: and rescue me out of the hand of strange children
column8: and their right hand is the right hand of iniquity

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 12 ^ qụórum fílii sicut novèllaĕ plantațiónes in juventúte sua. Fíliaĕ eórum compòsitaĕ~; circumornátaĕ ut similitúdo templi. ^ whose sons are as new plants in their youth. Their daughters decked out
qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: adorned round about after the similitude of a temple.
eructántia ex hoc in illud. Oves eórum foĕtósaĕ
et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: abundántes in egrèssibus suîs. ^ Their storehouses full
who teacheth my hands to fight: flowing out of this into that. Their sheep fruitful in young

1 ^ Benedìctus Dòminus Deus meus: 14 ^ Boves eórum crassaĕ. Non est ruína macèriaĕ
et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: nèqụe clamor in plassîs eórum. ^ Their oxen fat. There is no breach of wall
nor crying out in their streets.

qụi dòcet manûs meas ad práĕlium: cui haĕc sunt~; beátus pòpulus cujus Dòminus Deus ejus. ^ They have called the people happy
et dìģitos meos ad bellum. ^ Blessed be: that hath these things~; but happy is that people whose God is the Lord.
